'''Freeware''' (from "free" and "software") is computer [[software]] that is available for use at no cost or for an optional fee.<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/freeware Merriam-Webster definition of freeware]</ref> Freeware can be [[proprietary software]] available at zero price.<ref>{{cite book
+
'''Freeware''' (from "free" and "software") is computer [[software]] that is available for use at no cost or for an optional fee.<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/freeware Merriam-Webster definition of freeware]</ref>
  +   +
==History==
  +
The term ''freeware'' was coined by [[Andrew Fluegelman]] when he wanted to sell a communications program named [[PC-Talk]] that he had created but for which he did not wish to use traditional methods of distribution because of their cost.<ref>http://textfiles.fisher.hu/news/freeware.txt</ref> Fluegelman actually distributed PC-Talk via a process now referred to as [[shareware]]. Current use of the term freeware does not necessarily match the original concept by Andrew Fluegelman.
  +   +
==Criteria==
  +
Software classified as freeware is normally fully functional for an unlimited time with no cost, monetary or otherwise. Freeware can be [[proprietary software]] available at zero price.<ref>{{cite book
|last1= Dixon

|quote= Freeware, however, is generally only free in terms of price; the author typically retains all other rights, including the rights to copy, distribute, and make derivative works from the software.
|quote= Freeware, however, is generally only free in terms of price; the author typically retains all other rights, including the rights to copy, distribute, and make derivative works from the software.

â   â
==History==
  â
The term ''freeware'' was coined by [[Andrew Fluegelman]] when he wanted to sell a communications program named [[PC-Talk]] that he had created but for which he did not wish to use traditional methods of distribution because of their cost.<ref>http://textfiles.fisher.hu/news/freeware.txt</ref> Fluegelman actually distributed PC-Talk via a process now referred to as [[shareware]]. Current use of the term freeware does not necessarily match the original concept by Andrew Fluegelman.
  â   â
==Criteria==
  â
Software classified as freeware is normally fully functional for an unlimited time with no cost, monetary or otherwise. The software license may impose restrictions on the type of use including personal use, individual use, non-profit use, non-commercial use, academic use, commercial use or any combination of these. For instance, the license may be "free for personal, non-commercial use".
 
Accordingly, freeware may or may not be [[free and open source software]] and, in order to distinguish, the [[Free Software Foundation]] asks users to avoid calling "freeware" free software.<ref>http://www.fsf.org/licensing/essays/words-to-avoid.html#Freeware</ref> The principal difference being that free software can be used, studied, and modified without restriction; free software embodies the concept of "free speech" while freeware that of "free beer". Freeware is also different from [[shareware]]; the latter obliges the user to pay after some trial period or to gain additional functionality.<ref>{{cite web
Accordingly, freeware may or may not be [[free and open source software]] and, in order to distinguish, the [[Free Software Foundation]] asks users to avoid calling "freeware" free software.<ref>http://www.fsf.org/licensing/essays/words-to-avoid.html#Freeware</ref> The principal difference being that free software can be used, studied, and modified without restriction; free software embodies the concept of "free speech" while freeware that of "free beer".
